92Â Â AÂ noteÂ onÂ indicatorsÂ ofÂ performanceÂ ofÂ mandatedÂ definedÂ contributionÂ schemesÂ
Â InÂ additionÂ toÂ theÂ indicatorsÂ listedÂ above,Â theÂ ascentÂ ofÂ mandatedÂ definedÂ contributionÂ schemes,Â particularlyÂ inÂ LatinÂ AmericaÂ andÂ EasternÂ Europe,Â alongÂ withÂ severalÂ OECDÂ countries,Â hasÂ ledÂ toÂ researchÂ onÂ theÂ performanceÂ specificÂ toÂ thisÂ typeÂ ofÂ pensionÂ plan.Â Â TheÂ focusÂ ofÂ thisÂ researchÂ isÂ onÂ financialÂ performanceÂ andÂ severalÂ keyÂ indicatorsÂ tendÂ toÂ beÂ analyzedÂ inÂ theÂ crossâ€? countryÂ comparisons.35Â Â TheseÂ includeÂ netÂ andÂ grossÂ investmentÂ returnsÂ andÂ theirÂ volatility,Â chargeÂ ratiosÂ (theÂ impactÂ ofÂ feesÂ onÂ DCÂ balancesÂ overÂ theÂ accumulationÂ period,Â annuityÂ ratesÂ orÂ moneyâ€™sÂ worthÂ ratiosÂ andÂ theirÂ volatilityÂ andÂ theÂ dispersionÂ acrossÂ individualsÂ ofÂ eachÂ ofÂ theseÂ indicators).Â Â TheÂ compilationÂ ofÂ aÂ significantÂ bodyÂ ofÂ dataÂ onÂ theseÂ indicatorsÂ isÂ underÂ wayÂ atÂ bothÂ theÂ OECDÂ andÂ theÂ WorldÂ Bankâ€™sÂ financialÂ sectorÂ departmentÂ butÂ areÂ limitedÂ bothÂ byÂ problemsÂ withÂ reportingÂ standards36Â andÂ theÂ factÂ thatÂ mostÂ ofÂ theseÂ plansÂ haveÂ beenÂ introducedÂ onlyÂ sinceÂ theÂ midâ€?1990sÂ orÂ later.Â Â AsÂ theseÂ issuesÂ areÂ resolvedÂ andÂ dataÂ becomeÂ available,Â theyÂ willÂ beÂ includedÂ inÂ theÂ WorldÂ Bankâ€™sÂ pensionÂ database.Â
ConclusionsÂ andÂ lookingÂ forwardÂ
ThereÂ haveÂ beenÂ significantÂ advancesÂ inÂ theÂ developmentÂ andÂ collectionÂ ofÂ informationÂ andÂ dataÂ onÂ pensionÂ systemsÂ aroundÂ theÂ worldÂ duringÂ theÂ lastÂ decade.Â Â TheÂ microâ€?simulationÂ basedÂ comparativeÂ indicatorsÂ developedÂ atÂ theÂ OECDÂ areÂ nowÂ beingÂ producedÂ forÂ developingÂ countries.Â Â InÂ theÂ nextÂ fewÂ years,Â theseÂ indicatorsÂ willÂ beÂ updatedÂ andÂ refinedÂ forÂ anÂ evenÂ largerÂ groupÂ ofÂ countries.Â
ThereÂ areÂ stillÂ importantÂ gapsÂ toÂ beÂ addressed,Â however.Â Â AÂ majorÂ sourceÂ ofÂ usefulÂ informationÂ isÂ householdÂ surveysÂ thatÂ containÂ informationÂ aboutÂ theÂ relativeÂ incomesÂ andÂ povertyÂ ratesÂ ofÂ elderlyÂ individualsÂ asÂ wellÂ asÂ informationÂ onÂ householdÂ structuresÂ thatÂ areÂ changingÂ inÂ manyÂ countriesÂ inÂ waysÂ thatÂ canÂ influenceÂ theÂ needÂ forÂ pensionÂ provision.Â Â SocialÂ pensionsÂ areÂ beingÂ introducedÂ orÂ expandedÂ inÂ manyÂ countries,Â butÂ crossâ€?countryÂ dataÂ onÂ theirÂ performanceÂ isÂ scarce.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 35 Â Â SeeÂ HinzÂ et.Â alÂ eds.Â (2010)Â 36 Â Â SeeÂ HinzÂ et.Â alÂ eds.Â (AntolinÂ andÂ TapiaÂ Chapter,Â 2010).Â
93Â Â IndicatorsÂ ofÂ adequacyÂ couldÂ alsoÂ beÂ refined,Â forÂ example,Â toÂ takeÂ intoÂ accountÂ theÂ outâ€?ofâ€? pocketÂ healthÂ burdenÂ thatÂ disproportionatelyÂ affectÂ theÂ elderly.Â
WithÂ regardÂ toÂ longÂ runÂ sustainabilityÂ ofÂ unfundedÂ pensionÂ schemes,Â anÂ internationalÂ standardÂ forÂ fiscalÂ accountingÂ hasÂ remainedÂ elusive.Â Â AsÂ theseÂ liabilitiesÂ becomeÂ moreÂ prominent,Â evenÂ inÂ poorÂ countriesÂ withÂ youngÂ populations,Â robustÂ measuresÂ reportedÂ regularlyÂ areÂ requiredÂ forÂ betterÂ planningÂ andÂ toÂ informÂ policy.Â
CoverageÂ measuresÂ focusÂ onÂ â€˜snapshotsâ€™Â ofÂ contributorsÂ thatÂ doÂ notÂ captureÂ theÂ factÂ thatÂ manyÂ workersÂ moveÂ inÂ andÂ outÂ ofÂ contributoryÂ pensionÂ systems.Â Â MoreÂ informationÂ isÂ neededÂ toÂ assessÂ lifetimeÂ patternsÂ ofÂ contributionsÂ orÂ â€˜contributionÂ densitiesâ€™Â thatÂ provideÂ aÂ moreÂ accurateÂ pictureÂ ofÂ theÂ extentÂ toÂ whichÂ workersÂ haveÂ amassedÂ pensionÂ wealthÂ andÂ areÂ inÂ aÂ positionÂ toÂ financeÂ theirÂ retirement.Â Â
InÂ short,Â muchÂ workÂ remainsÂ toÂ beÂ doneÂ toÂ createÂ anÂ internationalÂ informationÂ baseÂ forÂ evidenceâ€?basedÂ pensionÂ policy.Â Â

2011,Â pleaseÂ visitÂ www.worldbank.org/spÂ Â Â Abstract
This paper presents and explains cross country data for mandatory publicly and privately managed pension systems around the world. Relevant World Bank demographic projections and other indicators previously reported in â€œInternational Patterns of Pension Provisionâ€? (2000) are updated, and relationships between key indicators are highlighted.
About this series...
Social Protection & Labor Discussion Papers are published to communicate the results of The World Bankâ€™s work to the development community with the least possible delay. The typescript manuscript of this paper therefore has not been prepared in accordance with the procedures appropriate to formally edited texts.

doc.repnme: International patterns of pension provision II : a worldwide overview of facts and figures
doc.abstracts: This paper presents and explains cross country data for mandatory publicly and privately managed pension systems around the world. This report is organized into three parts corresponding to three broad types of indicators. These indicators relate to: (i) the relevant contextual factors referred to here as environment; (ii) pension system design parameters; and (iii) indicators of performance. Part one of the report provides some information on the environment in which the system operates, focusing on demographic and labor market conditions. Understanding the current and future path of demographic patterns, especially aging, will place the later section on performance into a clearer perspective. Part two on pension system design uses a standardized taxonomy to describe differences across countries. The data on system design are presented in two groups of indicators: (i) overall architecture of the system: pillars, schemes including civil servants and other special schemes, and (ii) operating parameters of the system, which includes two sub-groups: a) qualifying conditions: pension eligibility ages, and contribution history, and b) contribution rates, defined benefit (DB), and defined contribution (DC) schemes, and indexation. It should be noted that while many countries have more than one program providing retirement income benefits, unless otherwise indicated, most of the data refer only to the national scheme. Part three presents a set of performance indicators. The indicators included are core pension indicators that illustrate six key criteria of any pension scheme, namely: (i) coverage, (ii) adequacy, (iii) financial sustainability, (iv) economic efficiency (i.e., minimizing the distortions of the retirement?income system on individuals' behavior, such as labor supply and savings outside of pension plans), (v) administrative efficiency, and (vi)) security of benefits in the face of different risks and uncertainties.
